name: 4-{(2E)-3-[4-(dimethylamino)phenyl]prop-2-enoyl}phenyl 2-methoxybenzoate
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1123
Reason: 4-{(2E)-3-[4-(dimethylamino)phenyl]prop-2-enoyl}phenyl has a melting point that we can analyze by considering its structural components. Starting with the basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C, we have substantial structural components to consider. The compound has two fused aromatic rings, which typically increase the melting point due to increased molecular rigidity and pi-stacking interactions; this effect is estimated to add about +25 °C for each additional fused ring. The molecular structure also includes a prop-2-enoyl group, which can increase the melting point due to the presence of a carbonyl group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and form a rigid structure, estimated at around +10 °C. Additionally, the phenyl group can contribute to the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding and form a rigid structure, estimated at around +20 °C. The methoxy group can also contribute to the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5 °C. The dimethylamino group can also contribute to the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5 °C. The presence of two methoxy groups can also contribute to the melting point due to their ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5 °C each.
